name: Institute for Understanding Anti-Palestinian Racism
theoryOfChange: The Institute for the Understanding of Anti-Palestinian Racism (IUAPR) bases its work on the 'Anti-Palestinian Racism: Naming, Framing and Manifestations' report by the Arab Canadian Lawyers Association (ACLA). This report serves as a framework that provides a description of anti-Palestinian racism, explains how it operates to silence discourse on Palestine, and outlines its impacts on individuals and the broader community. It is used as a working description and framework for institutions, organizations, companies, and individuals to address incidents of anti-Palestinian racism. The framework details various forms of anti-Palestinian racism, including denying the Nakba, justifying violence against Palestinians, failing to acknowledge Palestinians as an Indigenous people, erasing their human rights, excluding Palestinian perspectives, and defaming Palestinians and their allies.

evaluationSources: UNCORROBORATED: UCSF Institutional Review Board (IRB) approval for research

zakatClaimEvidence: The official website and donation pages of the Institute for the Understanding of Anti-Palestinian Racism (IUAPR) do not explicitly mention 'zakat' or 'zakat donations', nor do they indicate dedicated zakat funds or campaigns. The organization is a U.S. 501(c)(3) tax-exempt non-profit organization focused on research, education, and advocacy to end anti-Palestinian racism. (Source: https://antipalestinianracism.org/donate)

dimension_explanations.alignment: The alignment score of 16/50 indicates a moderate fit due to the high urgency of advocacy work, though there is a low specific fit for traditional Muslim donor expectations given the lack of established track record [1]. The organization is categorized as sadaqah-eligible for those looking to support general charitable causes [2].
dimension_explanations.impact: The impact score of 18/50 reflects a focus on capacity building through research and training programs [1]. However, the effectiveness of these programs is difficult to verify due to the lack of cost-per-beneficiary data and missing financial metrics in public filings [3].

strengths.detail: The organization fills an <cite id="2">underserved niche</cite> by focusing specifically on the systemic nature of anti-Palestinian racism.
The charity has successfully influenced academic discourse, with <cite id="4">40 faculty associations</cite> engaging with its research and framing.
The institute maintains a <cite id="7">well-defined theory of change</cite> that guides its research and reporting programs.

strengths_deep_dive: The Institute's primary strength lies in its ability to produce specialized research that addresses gaps in human rights reporting. By focusing on <cite id="3">naming and framing manifestations of racism</cite>, it provides a vocabulary for advocacy that was previously fragmented. Its impact is most visible in higher education, where it has tracked <cite id="4">40 faculty associations</cite> taking stances on definitions of racism. This suggests a high degree of relevance for donors interested in <cite id="1">academic freedom and civil rights advocacy</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: The Institute for the Understanding of Anti-Palestinian Racism Inc is a specialized nonprofit organization focused on <cite id="1">research, education, and advocacy</cite> regarding systemic discrimination. Operating primarily within the United States, the organization addresses a <cite id="2">niche human rights area</cite> by providing reporting mechanisms and training programs to the public. Its core mission involves <cite id="3">naming and framing the manifestations</cite> of anti-Palestinian racism to foster a more informed public discourse. The charity's work is particularly focused on institutional settings, as evidenced by its tracking of <cite id="4">faculty associations rejecting specific definitions</cite> that may impact academic freedom. While the organization provides critical <cite id="5">capacity-building services</cite>, it currently operates with limited public financial disclosures, which is common for emerging advocacy groups. Donors can support these efforts through <cite id="6">various digital giving methods</cite>, with all contributions classified as sadaqah. The organization maintains a <cite id="7">clear theory of change</cite> centered on the belief that systematic documentation and education are necessary precursors to policy shifts and social equity.
